Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a double-convex body, a long splayed flat- topped nozzle with a curved tip, a circular base-ring, and a leaf-shaped lug on each side. The filling-hole is surrounded by a double moulding. The shoulder is decorated with a snake-like wavy band design in relief with plastic dots, between the outer moulding of the filling-hole and a single moulding above the carination. On top of the nozzle is a ribboned thyrsos between two raised ridges, which end in volutes. Brown-orange micaceous Nile silt with reddish slip. Traces of burning around nozzle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by McLean Museum and Art Gallery, Greenock. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late Ptolemaic lamp, probably made in Naukratis. Parallels from Egypt, including Naukratis, in the British Museum (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q551,Q552, Q562, GR1965,0930.894, GR 1971,1224.6, GR 1886,0401.1360). Late 3rd to early 2nd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 331-4, Fig. 4a). Poor quality variant of a form with numerous parallels dated either late 2nd to 1st or late 3rd to 2nd century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 54-7, Type G, Fig. 78, who prefers earlier date). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.009) (Phase 1)
